sentences.sentence: As I was looking with wonder upon the sea that was so rough and terrible the day before, my companion, who had encouraged me to run away, came to me.
“Well, Bob,” said he, putting his hand on my shoulder, “How do you feel? I guess you were frightened, weren’t you, even of that little wind?”
“A little wind, you call it?” said I, “It was a terrible storm.”

“A storm, you fool,” he replied, “do you call that a storm? It was nothing at all. You’re just a fresh-water( 只习惯于在内河航行的 ) sailor, Bob. Come, let us have a glass or two of beer, and we’ll forget all that.”
To make short this sad part of my story, we went the way of all sailors—the beer was poured, and I got half drunk with it.
In that one night’s bad behavior I drowned( （借酒）消除 ) all my guilt, all my reflections upon my past conduct, and all my promises for the future.
But I was to have another trial still, and the next was to be much worse.
The sixth day of our being at sea, we came into Yarmouth Roads.
The wind had been blowing against us, and we had not gone far since the storm, and so here we were forced to anchor( 停（船） ) the ship.
The wind blew very hard for several days.
However, the Roads were thought to be as good as a harbor, and our ropes and sails were very strong. Our men were not worried, and spent the time in rest and laughter, as sailors like to do.
But on the eighth day the wind increased, and we all had to work to make everything tight( 紧的 ) and close, that the ship might ride as easy as possible.

By noon, the sea went very high indeed, and we thought once or twice our anchor( 锚 ) had come loose( 松动的 ). Then our captain had us pull up the down-wind( 顺风的 ) anchor( 锚 ), so that we rode with two up-wind( 逆风的 ) anchors( 锚 ), and the ropes fully stretched( 拉伸 ).
It was a terrible storm indeed, and now I began to see terror and amazement( 惊讶 ) in the faces even of the seamen themselves.
The captain passed me as he went in and out of his room, and I could hear him say softly to himself several times, “Lord, be merciful( 仁慈的 ) to us! We shall be all lost!”
I was overwhelmed( 不知所措的 ), and lay still in my room. I thought the danger of death was over, but when the captain himself came by( 靠近 ) me, and said we should be all lost, I was terribly frightened.
I got up out of my room and looked out, but such a horrible( 恐怖的 ) sight I never saw before.

The sea ran mountains high, and broke upon us every three or four minutes. Two ships that rode near us had cut their masts( 桅杆 ) at their base, and our men cried out that a ship about a mile ahead of us was sinking.
Towards the evening, the crew begged the captain of our ship to let them cut away the ship’s mast( 桅杆 ), which he was very unwilling to do.
But the crew cried to him that if he did not the ship would sink, and so he agreed to cut down the mast( 桅杆 ).
You can guess my reaction to all this, as I was just a young sailor, who had been frightened before at just a little storm.
But the worst had not come yet. The storm continued so strongly that the seamen themselves said they had never seen worse.
We had a good ship, but it was carrying a heavy load, so that the seamen every now and then( 不时 ) cried out that it would sink.
In the middle of the night, one of the men cried out that the ship was leaking( 漏水 ), and another said there was four feet of water in the ship. Then everyone was called to the pump.
At these words, my heart died within me, and I fell backwards( 向后 ) upon the side of my bed where I sat.
However, the men lifted me, and told me that I could pump as well as anyone. At this I got up, and went to the pump and worked very enthusiastically.
While this was doing, the captain ordered us to fire a gun as a signal for help.
I, who had no idea what they meant, thought that the ship had broken, or some horrible( 恐怖的 ) thing had happened.
I was so surprised that I fainted( 晕倒 ). As this was a time when everybody had his own life to think of, nobody noticed me.
It was a great while before I regained( 恢复 ) consciousness( 意识 ).
We worked on, but the water kept coming into the ship, and it was obvious that the ship would sink.
Though the storm began to decrease( 变小 ) a little, yet it was not possible that the ship could float until we reached a port, so the captain continued firing guns for help.
A small ship, which was just in front of us, sent a boat out to help us.

It was with the greatest danger that the boat came near us, but with the men in the boat risking their lives to( 冒着生命危险做... ) save ours, they came near enough that our men were able to throw them a rope and pull them close, after which we all got into their boat.
It was useless to think of returning to either ship. We all agreed to pull in( （船）靠岸 ) towards shore as much as we could.
Partly rowing and partly driven by the wind, our boat moved closer and closer to the shore.
Not much more than a quarter of an hour after we left our ship, we saw it sink.
That day I saw a ship sink for the first time.
I could hardly look up, when the seamen told me it was sinking. My heart was dead within me, partly with fear, partly with the thoughts of what was yet to come.
While we were in this situation, we could see a great many( 许多 ) people running along the shore to help us, when we should come near.
But we could only make  slow progress( 缓慢行进 ) towards the shore.
Finally we got in, though with much difficulty, and we all got safe on shore.
We walked afterwards( 后来 ) on foot to Yarmouth, where we were treated very well, particularly by merchants( 商人 ) and owners of ships.
We were given good rooms, and enough money to take us either to London, or back to Hull, as we wished.
If I had had the sense to go back home to Hull, I would have been very happy.
But my shame overcame my good judgment, and I thought how I should be laughed at among our neighbors.
As I stayed on land a while, the memory of the terror I had felt wore off( 逐渐消失 ).
As that faded( 逐渐消失 ), so did my desire to return home. At last I forgot about returning, and looked out for( 设法找到 ) a voyage.

analysis: 文中说：“The captain passed me as he went in and out of his room, and I could hear him say softly to himself several times, ‘Lord, be merciful to us! We shall be all lost! ’”所以选B。

analysis: 文中说：“Towards the evening, the crew begged the captain of our ship to let them cut away the ship’s mast.”所以选A。
